conflictDescription: User Story A requires the system to respond to caregiver's voice commands by asking clients if they feel unwell, while User Story B expects the system to respond directly to the older person's voice commands for mobility aid control without requiring permission. These impose opposite behaviors on the system for voice command handling.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to use voice commands to ask clients if they feel unwell, so I can respect their privacy and get their clear permission before acting.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person with mild mobility issues, I want to use voice commands to control ALFRED easily and independently.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking all non-emergency notifications during caregiver work hours, while User Story B requires pausing reminders during older adult talks. These two stories specify different conditions for pausing or blocking notifications, which could cause conflict in notification behavior under overlapping conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours so I can focus on patients without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to pause reminders during my talks, so I can focus on conversations without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during caregiver work hours, while User Story B requires ALFRED to stop health reminders during family video calls for the older person. Both stories demand stopping notifications but under different events and operations, which can conflict when notifications overlap.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours so I can focus on patients without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to stop health reminders during family video calls so I can enjoy my social time without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during caregiver work hours, which forbids sending such notifications. User Story B wants ALFRED to send notifications when the older person drinks herbal tea, which is a non-emergency notification. These two stories give opposite instructions about sending non-emergency notifications in overlapping time frames.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours so I can focus on patients without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person I want to tell ALFRED only when I drink my herbal tea so that I keep control and avoid unwanted messages.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all notifications during caregiver shifts, which means stopping reminders at all times. User Story B wants reminders to pause only during older person's talks, meaning reminders continue otherwise. These are opposite instructions about when notifications should happen, causing a conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block all notifications during my shifts to avoid distractions and focus only on urgent health tasks.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to pause reminders during my talks, so I can focus on conversations without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all notifications during caregiver shifts (stop notifications), while User Story B wants to stop health reminders only during family video calls (a specific time). Both ask to stop notifications, but User Story A is general and forbids notifications during shifts, conflicting with User Story B's requirement to allow notifications except during social moments.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block all notifications during my shifts to avoid distractions and focus only on urgent health tasks.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to stop health reminders during family video calls so I can enjoy my social time without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all notifications during caregiver shifts, forbidding notifications, while User Story B requires the system to allow the older person to send notifications about drinking herbal tea. These two impose opposite system behaviors regarding notifications in the same cluster.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to block all notifications during my shifts to avoid distractions and focus only on urgent health tasks.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person I want to tell ALFRED only when I drink my herbal tea so that I keep control and avoid unwanted messages.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking non-emergency notifications during caregiver work hours, while User Story B requires pausing reminders during older adult talks. These specify different triggering events for controlling notifications, which are inconsistent for the same operation of pausing or blocking notifications.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours so I can avoid distractions and focus only on urgent patient care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to pause reminders during my talks, so I can focus on conversations without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to block non-emergency notifications during caregiver work hours, while User Story B wants ALFRED to stop health reminders during social calls. Both require ALFRED to stop notifications but in different contexts, which may conflict if the system cannot distinguish or handle these stopping actions separately.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours so I can avoid distractions and focus only on urgent patient care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to stop health reminders during family video calls so I can enjoy my social time without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during caregiver shifts, while User Story B expects ALFRED to allow notifications when the older person confirms drinking herbal tea. These are opposite expectations for handling notifications, creating a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours so I can avoid distractions and focus only on urgent patient care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person I want to tell ALFRED only when I drink my herbal tea so that I keep control and avoid unwanted messages.

conflictDescription: User Story A allows informal caregivers to receive notifications selectively for clients they choose, while User Story B requires nurse check-ins only when the older person arranges them, forbidding unsolicited check-ins. This creates a conflict on when notifications or check-ins can start.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to accept notifications from ALFRED only for the clients I choose, so I respect their privacy and avoid too many alerts.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want nurse check-ins only when I arrange them at home, so I feel safe and in control.
